Fields.DialogueText: Morganas have been sighted along the coast!
Move us to engage, sailor. U-29, do you have a firing solution?
Bring us three degrees Backbord.
Aye aye!
Torpedos away!
Torpedoes away!
Damn... miss!
Kapitän, the enemy is moving in.
@BATTLE
Ja, Kapitän?

Fields.MenuText: Are you okay? You rarely miss.
We wasted a torpedo back there. Let's be more careful next time.
Could it be that even U-29 has the occasional moment of fallibility?

Fields.DialogueText: Ja. And I assure you that I shan't be making a habit of it, Kapitän.
I will try to avoid making another mistake, Kapitän.
No one is perfekt.
Very well.
And as you can see on the map here, the Nixen are advancing south at a steady pace along the coast...
*snort*
What was that, U-29?
What? Nothing. Bitte fahrt fort.
Are you okay?
Of course I am, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: Did you know that you were snoring a few moments ago?
Is Lt. Kurtz boring you?
Well, it just seemed like you were sleeping.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't snore.
Nein! Of course not, Kapitän.
I may have been resting my eyes.
I'm worried about you, U-29.
I insist. I'm fine, Kapitän.
Then it's time to put that to the test.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
What do you have there, U-29?
Oh, it's just a trinket.
Is there a face on that necklace?
Ja. It's a face in Alabaster, with a Loorbeerkranz.

Fields.MenuText: Sounds frivolous...
A laurel crown! Is it Greek or Roman?
Interesting. Where's it from?

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose it is, Kapitän. Come to think of it, there's something strange about the trinket.
I am not sure of its origin.
Originally? It's hard to determine - though I haven't given up on finding out.
In any case, it is quite old.
*ALARM*
You may want to put it somewhere safe.
@BATTLE
That bird over there has gray plumage. Das ist interessant.
Hello there, U-29!
Hallo, Kapitän.
Taking notes on the local wildlife?
Ja. There are some fascinating sea birds in this area.

Fields.MenuText: Rough night?
You look absolutely terrible.
You look exhausted!

Fields.DialogueText: Ja. I had.
Ja wirklich? That bad?
Ja. And there's a reason for that.
Are you okay?
Of course. I've just had some trouble sleeping lately.
You look like you're about to fall over!
I'll be fine, Kapitän.
You know as well as I do that you've been having some performance issues - let's not let them get any worse. U-29, I am ordering you to take today off.
*sigh*
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
I do appreciate the thought, though.
Everyone, get to your Station!
@BATTLE
The threat is neutralized, Kapitän.
Very good, Leutnant.
That was some good fire control, U-29.
Danke. It's good of you to say.
I take it you're feeling better?
Ja. Getting some rest was just what I needed, I think.

Fields.MenuText: Good. We need you to be in peak fighting condition.
I was getting worried about you, U-29.
Just make sure that you get plenty of sleep tonight.

Fields.DialogueText: I will be, Kapitän.
I appreciate your concern.
Ja. Thank you.
Excuse me, Kapitän. Have you seen my Füller?
No, I have not seen your fountain pen. Do you suppose that someone took it?
I don't think so. I just noticed it wasn't where I had left it. I probably just misplaced it.
Well, if I see it, I'll let you know.
And I will, too.
I just don't understand where it could have gone. We're on a U-Boot! It's not that big of a place. Er, pardon me, Schiffsdame.
Ja, of course. Where was the Füller, the last time you saw it?
In my Seemannskiste. I didn't use it every day, but I know I had it the day before yesterday, because I used it to update the logs.
Interesting.

Fields.MenuText: U-29, don't you think there are better uses for your time?
Any luck yet?
Remember, it is just a pen.

Fields.DialogueText: I can't pass up a mystery, big or small.
There's no such thing as luck.
It's not about the pen, Kapitän. It's about the pursuit.
Well, be that as it may, I think the pursuit of the pen is low on our collective list of priorities. I'm sorry, Lieutenant, but we have a ship to run.
*ALARM*
Case in point!
@BATTLE
I am sorry, Leutnant, but I've searched everywhere. I can't find your Füller, and I can't imagine where it could be.
It really is a Rätsel, isn't it?
Ja. It is.
It was a good Füller, too. It cost me five Mark.
Have you given up on looking for his pen?
As much as it pains me to admit it, Kapitän, I have. It looks like we might have a simple case of a lost Füller.

Fields.MenuText: I can't believe I'm saying this, but I think you could be wrong.
You may have to re-evaluate that analysis, U-29.
Or not.

Fields.DialogueText: Ist das so, Kapitän?
I'm always happy to do so, Kapitän, when confronted with new evidence.
What evidence do you have?
I've received several reports today of missing items, including watches, tools, and pens. It looks like we might have a thief on board.
Ah. Das ist sehr interessant.
That's one way of putting it.
*ALARM*
Go to your stations!
@BATTLE
Everyone, get to your Station!
@BATTLE
Dammit!
Kapitän?
That thief stole my pocket watch.
Ah, you obviously agree that this is a problem.
I more than agree.

Fields.MenuText: We need to get to the bottom of this, so I can throw the offender in the brig.
This is a small crew in a very confined space. Without trust, morale can collapse in a matter of days.
Though, yeah, I really want that watch back.

Fields.DialogueText: Just make sure the thief doesn't steal the key.
Ja. A valid concern.
Find the culprit, and we'll find the plunder.
Have you had any luck finding my cufflinks, Kapitän?
No, we haven't, sailor. Wait. Why do you need cufflinks on a submarine?
They bring good luck, Kapitän.
Where are you from, sailor?
München. Kapitän.
That makes sense.
Ah. The watch has sentimental value, I take it?
I'd almost call it a family heirloom.
But, more than that, the crime spree is accelerating - and our thief is becoming more bold.
Everyone, get to your Station!
@BATTLE
Kapitän, I've been thinking.
Oh?
Ja. I'm a fan of it. Anyway, it occurs to me -- all of the items that have gone missing have been valuable, in one way or another.

Fields.MenuText: Which implies considerable powers of observation, I suppose.
Where is this going?
Did it take you long to reach this conclusion?

Fields.DialogueText: Ja, but wait for me to finish.
Just wait, Kapitän.
Now, will let me continue?
Not all of the items were expensive. Your watch, I am sorry to say, is a rather cheap one, even if it has been with you for many years.
It's value for you lies in sentiment, not money. Lt. Kurtz prized his Füller because it was expensive. One crew member lost a picture of his family. I could continue on and on.
Do you see? Whoever is stealing these items is taking them because they're seen as valuable, not because he or she thinks they can sell them for money.
So it's meant to wound the crew rather than be a source of profit to the thief? Wonderful.
Well, what do we have here?
What the hell is that?
Hmm. It appears to be a marking painted on the bulkhead. A symbol of some kind.
That wasn't there yesterday. Did our thief leave it for us?
To the extent that unusual events in a closed environment are likely to stem from a common source, that seems to be a reasonable explanation.
Reasonable or not, I don't like it.
Kapitän.
You look tired. Did you get enough sleep last night?
Nein. I was up late reading. I think I may have deduced the meaning of that strange Symbol we saw yesterday.
Oh, really?
You can find a picture of it in this book, if you have the desk space. I've marked the page.

Fields.MenuText: Are you suggesting that we have some sort of cultist on board?
What?
Wait. You have a collection of books about esoteric Renaissance symbology?

Fields.DialogueText: Basically, ja.
It's an ancient symbol that's associated with the Okkultem. Would you like me to say that again?
I'm glad you asked. I enjoy belaboring the obvious.
Right. What do you think we should do?
Do you mean for now? I can't imagine anything different. But we need to be aware, Kapitän.
Of what?
Whoever this thief is, their motivation extends beyond simple avarice. And it may be something more than psychological warfare as well.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
It appears to be a simplified mirror image of the Dei Vivi from the Liber juratus, but I believe it's actually meant to signify the Sigillum Baphometi of the self-proclaimed anti-pope of....
Um.

It's an occult symbol. It dates back to what is believed to have been a Renaissance fraud, but in certain circles it's claimed to be much older. And there are Byzantine references to support the claim.
Kapitän, can I have a moment of your time?
Of course.
I have compiled information from all the disappearances, and I have deduced that, based on the timeline of objects being reported missing, the thefts must be happening at night.
That was already the working assumption.
Ja. And now it is established fact.

Fields.MenuText: U-29, you still look tired.
I felt like it was a reasonable assumption.
You're right. The more facts that we are certain of, the better.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't change the subject, Kapitän.
I find that there are no reasonable assumptions.
Evidence shall be the net we weave tight around the culprit.
Now that we know the thefts are happening at night, I am going to station a special watch to look out for them.
*ALARM*
Prepare to submerge!
@BATTLE
Kapitän, there's another Symbol on a bulkhead again.
Yes, and I've gotten another missing object report. It seems that our special watch didn't accomplish much. What was the symbol?
Akin to the others. I believe it's part of a Sequenz.
Ah, Leutnant. Good to see you. How did the watch go?
We didn't see anything, Kapitän. I don't know how, but that thief slipped right past us.

Fields.MenuText: Strange. U-29, what do you think?
I don't like this. Could it be occultism? Hidden thieves in the night?
We are going to have to watch more closely.

Fields.DialogueText: I am not sure, Kapitän. Is everyone on the watch trustworthy?
Now you are starting to sound superstitious, Kapitän.
For now, it seems to be the only course of action.
U-29, I want you and me to lead the watch next time.
Very well, Kapitän.
*ALARM*
Well, we can't forget there's a war going on.
@BATTLE
Everyone, get to your Station!
@BATTLE
It has been a few hours already. I don't think the thief is going to show.
Well, let's wait anyway.
Aren't you tired?
I'm used to being tired.
Are you still not sleeping well?
Nein. Though I manage. Kapitän?
Yes, U-29?
If I may ask: why do you care so much about catching this thief?

Fields.MenuText: I want my damn watch back.
I would think it's a proportionate response to a string of thefts and apparent cult activity on my watch.
At this point, I'm just curious. How are they evading us so well?

Fields.DialogueText: I guess I could understand that, Kapitän, although that's not how I operate on a personal level.
It's your duty, then? I understand.
Me, too, Kapitän.
Well, that's Leutnant Schuler with the next watch. Let's call it a day.
You might be interested, Kapitän, to hear that there were no reported thefts last night, and no new symbols have appeared.
Is that really true?
Ja. I believe it's linked to our nighttime watch.
Go on.
Whoever's doing this is afraid of us. Either you, because you are the Kapitän, or me, because I am a Walküre.

Fields.MenuText: I think they must be afraid of me. It's probably obvious I'm the one more ready to throw the perpetrator overboard.
I would guess that the thief's also afraid of you, U-29.
Who do you think the thief is more afraid of, me or you?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, are you sure about that, Kapitän?
I had come to the same conclusion, Kapitän.
Honestly, Kapitän, I think our cultist was frightened off by me, not you.
Our culprit, whether Mannschaft or blinder Passagier, has some education in okkulten Traditionen. We can take this as Fakt even if the Symbole themselves are meant as diversions.
My Natur and powers are presumably outside of that experience. Perhaps I'm feared, or perhaps it's only wariness, but I assume that I'm considered an unknown Variable - and therefore dangerous.
*ALARM*
Care to demonstrate how dangerous you can be?
@BATTLE
What's all this commotion about?
It's one of the sailors, Kapitän. He says he saw... something last night.
The thief?
Nein. I... think you should ask him yourself.
Well...
It was a ghost! A ghost, I say!
Don't be ridiculous.
I am telling you the truth! It was horrible...
Now is not the time to dive headlong into superstition.
Seriously? We are literally at war with talking warships, and you're telling me not to be superstitious?
First we must exclude more conventional explanations. We turn first to science, always, or we fumble in the dark.
... I do find the idea of ghosts intriguing, however.

Fields.MenuText: ... So it really is a ghost, right?
What do you make of this, U-29?
Be that as it may, right now we just need the facts. No assumptions about what you saw.

Fields.DialogueText: I couldn't say, Kapitän, but I doubt it.
I wish I knew, Kapitän.
You are in the right spirit, Kapitän.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Everyone, get to your Station!
@BATTLE
I want a full damage report.
Kapitän, I don't think the damage here to the engine is from the battle.
Tell me about it.
I was in the middle of checking things over this morning when the battle began, Kapitän, but this damage doesn't look right. It looks like sabotage.
Kapitän, look - there's an accompanying Symbol. And writing this time... threatening writing, at that.
It's intensifying, whatever it is.
There's something else. I should have known about this damage. I should have felt it. Why didn't I?

Fields.MenuText: Don't ask me.
I was about to ask you the same question.
Are you still convinced that it's not supernatural?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, sorry, Kapitän. I wasn't.
Ah.
Not entirely, Kapitän. Not anymore.
Great. Just great.
There you are, U-29. Wait, did you sleep last night?
No. I was too busy researching those strange Symbole.
Using what books? Authors Harold Harst, Tom Shark, John King -- they wrote pulp novels! What good are those books?
No, not those books. The ones beneath them.
I see Occultism in the 20th Century, Vril, Necronomicon. Wait, is that book bound with...
The Symbole are all part of a pattern of summoning and binding. It's hard to describe precisely. They allow for a supernatural entity to exist within our world.
A member of this Kult would use them to summon something from... beyond here.
Of course, there's nothing to any of this - but if we take it at face value, it does show us that the Person whom we are dealing with here intends to do us great harm.
I assume a greater ritualistic... service of some kind is underway.

Fields.MenuText: So why is the thief stealing the stuff?
So how does this fit in?
What would this ritual require?

Fields.DialogueText: I believe they are being used, in the mind of this thief, to power the Ritual.
I believe the thefts are merely a way for the thief to provide "fuel" for the Ritual.
Good question, Kapitän.
This Ritual calls for the sacrifice of objects of importance. The more personally important the Objekt is to the owner, the more power it lends to the Ritual.
*ALARM*
I don't like any of this. Let's talk more later.
@BATTLE
Kapitän! Kapitän!
I'm here! What's wrong?
Kapitän, one of the Mannschaft went missing last night!
Sailor, start a search - there are only so many places on this vessel where you can hide a body, living or dead. And bring me U-29.
Ja, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: What does this thief want with my crew?
The thief will end up sacrificing our crew member, right?

Fields.DialogueText: Remember... objects are important to all of us, but they are even more important to thieves.
Unless the thief gets caught, ja, the Mannschaftsmitglieder will be sacrificed.
I shudder to think of it.
U-29, where were you?
Resting. Sorry, I didn't sleep well last night.
*ALARM*
Right. This never happens at a good time.
@BATTLE
Everyone, get to your Station!
@BATTLE
There's still no sign of the missing crew member.
Thank you, Leutnant.
Ja?
Where did you get that bruise on your face?
What bruise?... I don't know, Kapitän.
U-29, do you have a history of sleepwalking?
Nein. I don't think so.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe you should think again.
Perhaps there's a reason behind why we couldn't find the thief.
Can you remember anything from these last several nights?

Fields.DialogueText: Sleepwalking?
When we stayed up for him... he was afraid of me.
Nein. I can't. Only strange dreams, including flickers and wisps that vanish upon waking.
We will follow you tonight after you fall asleep. Maybe this will finally shed some light on the situation.
I think that would be a very good Idee, Kapitän.
Shhh... here she comes.
What!?
Of course! U-29 prefers her physical state, but Belles can appear as phantoms. That must be what that frightened sailor saw.
She's heading somewhere, Kapitän.
Let's follow.
Of course, a hidden panel.
I would never have been able to tell it was there.
IŠ! IŠ! IŠ!
Can you see in there, Kapitän?
I can, and I don't like it. Our missing sailor is in there!
Here she comes! IŠ! IŠ! IŠ! Here she comes!
*ALARM*
Ah!
She's awake!
Just in time, too.

Fields.MenuText: Are you okay?
Quick! Tell me what you remember from your dream!
Talk to me, U-29.

Fields.DialogueText: I think so, Kapitän. Oh, but I don't feel well.
A broad flat plain, and on that plain was a great building of green stone blocks, full of horrible statues - I don't want to think about it.
I am here, Kapitän. Es geht mir gut.
@BATTLE
Will Maat Schmidt be all right?
He should be. The question is, will you?
I don't know, Kapitän.
U-29, when did you start having trouble sleeping?
A few weeks ago. Actually, it was around that time.
How did you acquire that necklace?

Fields.MenuText: U-29, you have to tell me.
What more do you know?
I demand you tell me.

Fields.DialogueText: Ja. Ja, I started losing sleep when I found the necklace.
The necklace is tied to all this.
Very well, Kapitän. I think the necklace is important to this.
We need to get rid of that necklace.
*ALARM*
Oh, look at that, time to go! I guess we have to talk later, Kapitän.
Wait!
@BATTLE
U-29, we must be rid of that thing! Don't you see?
I don't, Kapitän. It has tremendous artistic and historical value.
It's also affecting your thoughts! It's causing you to sleepwalk at night! It almost made you kill Schmidt!
I can't, Kapitän.
Can't, or won't?
I just can't. I see its face in my dreams. Standing on the high tower of hewn green blocks, she mocks.
I could not remember before, but now I can. I just can't bring myself to get rid of it.
I can get rid of it. I'm going to take it from you and throw it overboard.
Wait!
There. It's done!

Fields.MenuText: I hope this is all finished, now.
Do you feel better?
Could it really be this easy?

Fields.DialogueText: Me too, Kapitän.
Ja. Not much, but a little.
I just don't know, Kapitän.
*ALARM*
You can sit this one out if you need to.
Nein, I think I'll somehow manage.
@BATTLE
Everyone, get to your Station!
@BATTLE
Are you feeling better?
Nein. I still see her in my dreams.

Fields.MenuText: I thought we would be rid of that thing.
Is the depth of the sea not far enough to break the link?
Dreams, cults, and symbols! Who would have thought of such a thing?

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitän, when it comes to the Okkultem, it's seldom that easy.
With the Okkulten, that's hard to say.
The Okkulte can be hard to stomach, can't it?
So have you changed your mind about this being supernatural?
Let's just say that, in this case, I have experienced enough evidence to change my Hypothese.
Let's try to, maybe, focus on the positive... have you read anything good lately?
Somehow, I just haven't found the time to read much. Ah, Captain!
What?!
It's back! The necklace!
I see it! Where did it come from, U-29?
Here she comes!
*ALARM*
It's not a Morgana, Kapitän!
Is it a phantom?
It looks just like our ship!
(Over intercom system) IŠ! IŠ! Here she comes! Prepare!
@BATTLE
I have to get back to U-29.
The whole U-Boot is rocking!
That's probably not a good sign.
A dead youth lives on his dead plain forever! IŠ! Here she comes!
That's also probably not a good sign.
Aiii!
I've got the necklace! And now I am smashing it!
Aiii!

Fields.MenuText: Hey. Hey! You're okay. Look at me.
I smashed it... it's fixed now, right?
U-29, I'm not sure these pulp novels are good for you.

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitän, I'm going to sleep now.
I am feeling better than I have in a long time, Kapitän... a long time. Good night.
I'm tired, but I have experienced worse.
I think it's a good sign that you're sleeping.
Captain, Morganas to starboard!
Everyone, get to your Station!
@BATTLE
How are you feeling, U-29?
Have you been sleeping well?
Like a Baby, Kapitän.
I am glad. Just as long as you're not reading those infernal books!
Hey, get back up there, Kapitän!
I'm just kidding. Read whatever you want. After what you've been through, you deserve it.
I suppose I have, haven't I? Now, if you will excuse me, I have a pressing engagement with Detektiv Mr. Harold Harst.
Of course. I don't want to keep you from leaving.

Fields.MenuText: Well. Let's never do that again.
... I am so glad that she's safe.

Fields.DialogueText: Wütend. Thank you for asking.
That's fair.

Venom was responsible for some of it - for creating that poisoned necklace in the first place. I saw her there, in those last Visionen. I fought to stay inside them, really. To learn what she had done.
... And did you?
Enough to make a necklace of my own, I think. A kind of Amulett. Protection, perhaps.
Well, be damn careful about it. Never mind the risk to the crew - stories about possessed Belles could be calamitous to the war effort.
... Have you reported this?
Sure. I said a crew member had seen a ghost.
Ah.
